question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The lines defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\]and
\[\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ 2 \\ -10 \end{pmatrix} + u \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\]intersect at $P.$  Find the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ in degrees.
inference:
The direction vectors of the two lines are
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},\]respectively.  The cosine of the angle between the two lines is
\[\cos \theta = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\Vert \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\Vert \left\Vert \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\Vert} = \frac{2 - 1 + 2}{\sqrt{4 + 1 + 1} \sqrt{1 + 1 + 4}} = \frac{3}{\sqrt{6} \sqrt{6}} = \frac{1}{2}.\]Therefore,
\[\theta = \cos^{-1} \frac{1}{2} = \boxed{60^\circ}.\]
Final Answer: \boxed{60^\circ}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then
\[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{3}{\sqrt{6} \sqrt{6}} = \frac{1}{2}.\]Hence, $\theta = \boxed{60^\circ}.$
